comments.commentBody:
You advise doing, "whatever it takes to ensure your financial security," but the whole point here is that there IS no such thing as financial security. Owning a home outright isn't going to compensate for long stretches of unemployment/underemployment. In fact, it's more likely to tie you to one place, so you lose out on job opportunities that may exist elsewhere. I know people who bought before the housing bubble burst, and now they are stuck with those houses; because they owe more than the houses are now worth, they would have to come up with tens of thousands of dollars in cash to be able to sell them.

And forget refinancing in our 30s and 40s, a lot of us are getting our first mortgages at that time. Most people I know are getting married in their late-twenties to mid-thirties, and then buying together. That's what I did. My husband and I are fortunately not under water (thanks to a hefty down payment, and regularly paying more than what's due), but after nearly 8 years, it would be nice to have some equity in the place.

Part of our anxiety as thirty-somethings is knowing that we can only save so much, can only plan for so many problems. Ultimately, if we get hit with a long stretch of unemployment or a serious illness, we won't be able to recover financially. The opportunities and safety nets just aren't there. My heart goes out to those boomers who are living the reality I fear may be my future.

I have one good friend and neighborhood who has been unemployed due to his place of employment going out of business at the beginning of the recession.  He is in his mid 50s and was the former manager of a art photography development lab - quite well known - in San Francisco.  He is looking for any job he can find with benefits - he's responsible, reliable, very smart and obviously talented.  He's been out of work now for 3 years, living on marginal employment or UI.  Only after he lands a job, and believe me, he, my family and his friends have been looking on his behalf, we will truly believe that the job market is improving.  Thanks for listening.
What took her so long?

Who cares? why is this even news?
We still have a war, we are about to become bankrupt,a dn we have massive unemployment and crazy people shooting kids in the head?
It is wasteful to dedicate inteleectual capital to the musings of an entertainer, and her sexual orientation, whcih I couldn't care less about.

I also think that people misunderstood the words at the end, which led them to believe that she was quitting acting. I think she believed that by coming out as gay, she would no longer get the big roles, the movies opening on "three thousand screens" as she said. I think she believed by going public that she was imperiling her career as an actress. I think it's a hugely positive sign that few people read it that way--why would this affect her career? Love Jodie Foster.

I just watched it (not the sort of thing I would normally find myself exposed to).  I don't understand what's hard to understand.  I think people are confused because she was being honest & personal in a context that is designed for falsenss and publicity.
Love Jodie's Speech, Cydney Bernard's bio and pics are here http://showbizdaily.net/celebrity-bio/cydney-bernard-is-jodie-fosters-ex... in case you are interested
She gave a truly eloquent and moving speech describing, almost poetically, who and what she really cares about. It was understated and low key. Very, very wonderful!
My surprise lay elsewhere. I was suprised Jodie Foster won a lifetime achievement award now. Despite a good body of work, at 50, she seems rather young to be collecting such an award.

I would imagine living through the horror of being a teenager stalked by John Hinckley, Jr. and then "honored" by his assassination attempt of Ronald Reagan would make privacy a major issue for Ms. Foster.  Good for her for living her life with creativity and dignity.  And good for her for standing by her friends, whether we like them or not.  It's hard to believe she's getting slagged in the comments when she should be an object of admiration.

Why, in 2013, only sort of come out? Perhaps it's a result of being coached by Mel Gibson. I'd rather she be talking to, maybe, Ian McKellen, or Ellen DeGeneris (who, by the way, had her own defensive privacy issues, but has learned that she doesn't have to be an "activist", or whatever she thought she was expected to be, to be herself). These are just two alternatives to the Honey Boo Boo-style of openness that horrifies Foster.

Privacy means it's nobody's business about the specifics of your life, but when you've reached a level of wealth, influence, and power, (and 50!) isn't it time to be less coy about the simple fact of your sexual orientation? Many other younger actors are coming out early, when the bigotry and preconceived perceptions of others could still actually hurt their careers.

When you're young and struggling with this information about yourself, it really does matter how others around you are handling these issues, even, and sometimes especially, public figures.

Do I really need to have met her in person to be privileged to know this about a public figure such as herself?

All this hand-wringing over this - who cares??  Why she even felt she needed to say anything at all is something of a mystery.  Would rather she have just made a simple thank-you speech and made a graceful exit.  Celebrities!  *eye roll*

I'm a little confused. As far as I can tell, no one has cared about Jodie Foster nor her private life the better part of 2 decades. I found it to be odd and strange to ramble on about something no one gives a dam about. Jodie Foster is gay?

Next thing we'll learn >>> The sky is blue...get over yourself honey...no one would watch your reality show.

Just goes to show that a respected and well-liked legend can deliver a rambling self-serving speech, much of which was not appropriate for this forum, and still be called brilliant. I love Jodie but, holy cow, the speech was very strange.

Are people so dense these days that one must make absolutely explicit declarations to appreciate the message someone is sending or the point being made?  Read literature much? I would have been surely disappointed had someone of Foster's intellect given her speech in any other fashion.

Jodie Foster's peek-a-boo, coy "am I or am I not" routine was too little and far too late.  Bravo to Ellen and Rosie for having the courage to come out  without  the kittenish and maudlin words so cleverly crafted and, I'm fairly sure, well-rehearsed that Jodie used so eloquently. She's an Oscar winner,folks. They're good at line-reading.  She could have done something positive for the Gay/Lesbian community but took the easier path.  Points to Jodie for her acting.  Points taken away for the feeble attempt to create drama but give nothing of value away. That, and the lauding of  Mel Gibson, an inveterate racist, anti-Semite and woman-abuser was reprehensible, indeed.  Glossing over his track record makes me think this was an attempt to bring him back into the show business fold.  I hope people are more intelligent than to fall for this bid to cleanse his reputation.  All things considered, not Ms. Foster's finest seven minutes.

When Jodie Foster talks about privacy, it is not the same as George Clooney or some other A-lister decrying paparazzi attention. Ms. Foster, while a student at Yale, was stalked and harassed by John Hinckley, Jr., who ultimately shot President Reagan to get her attention. Try dealing with that -- and the aftermath (which included throngs of media following her around) when you're 20. Another deranged fan followed her around campus. He ultimately said he didn't shoot her because "she was too pretty." She had to have a bodyguard.

So her privacy was compromised in a much more violent and terrifying way than most other stars.

As to Mel Gibson, she has been quoted saying she doesn't defend his actions, but that when your friend is struggling, you don't go in the opposite direction.

Jodie Foster did not prepare her acceptance speech, instead she decided to do it impromptu and what came out was a stream of conscious, kind of like the way events in one's memory replay in a rush. If you know her, then I suppose what she said had a lot more meanings that it did for everyone else.

My family and I watched the Golden Globes last night and were a little dismayed at Jodie Foster's speech.  While we think she is a great actress and we very much enjoy her movies, we were a little  bewildered why she would make another declaration of her being gay (the world already knew that) but at the same time asking for privacy.  Personally, I would have taken note of  previous great actors acceptance speeches for their life time achievement award and how it is done with grace and style.
Not revealing anything that has not been well known by everyone except Hinckley.

That was the most wonderful celeb speech I have heard. Kind of a James Joyce novella passed through a beautiful and passionate tiger women hinting at the deeply bright star personal performance art that will be revealed.

The nature of her art will be revealed within the context of her vulnerability and passion of the moment.

The hypocrasy has nothing to do with Hollywood.  Jesse Jackson is called an anti-racist activist even though he calls NYC "Hymietown" and our President the N word.  He performed his minstal show of pain over Michael Richards rant although he defended the anti-semetic Jerimiah Wright and had no problem taking part in a round table discussion with Louis Farrakhan.  This isn't just one person or instance.  The "civil rights/anti-racism" industry is full of such characters.

Jodie Foster's revelation was hardly that. You would have to live under a rock for her not to be considered "out". Besides the meandering and often non-nonsensical nature of her remarks the worst part of it was her continued association with the bigoted misogynist anti-semite Mel Gibson. How a "proud" LGBT woman could associate herself with a man who symbolizes the worst in patriarchy, violence against women and religious hatred is beyond me. It bespeaks a hypocrisy so prevalent in Hollywood that intolerance is only tolerated if the perpetrator is a fellow celebrity or a pal.
Holy mackerel-who cares? She's out. Welcome. Next?
What a beautiful speech.  I am shocked because I read so much trash about it before getting the chance to see and hear it myself.
Brilliant, moving and in control. Nothing unusual, whatsoever.
